{% endraw %}

Maximum Sum Subarray of Size K

Given an array of positive numbers and a positive number 'k', find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size 'k'.

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
arr = [2, 1, 5, 1, 3, 2]
k = 3
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
naive_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k(arr, k)

9
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N*K)
Space Complexity: O(1)

{% raw %}

naive_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k[source]

naive_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k(arr, k)

Given an array of positive numbers and a positive number 'k', find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size 'k'.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert naive_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k(arr, k) == 9
{% endraw %}

Can we do better, in terms of time complexity? Yes, we can!

{% raw %}

optimal_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k[source]

optimal_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k(arr, k)

Given an array of positive numbers and a positive number 'k', find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size 'k'.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
arr = [2, 1, 5, 1, 3, 2]
k = 3
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
optimal_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k(arr, k)

9
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)

{% raw %} 
assert optimal_solution_to_max_sum_subarray_of_size_k(arr, k) == 9
{% endraw %}

Smallest Subarray with a Greater Sum

Given an array of positive integers and a number 'S', find the length of the smallest contiguous subarray whose sum is greater than of equal to 'S'. Return 0 if no such subarray exists.

{% raw %}

smallest_subarray_sum[source]

smallest_subarray_sum(arr, s)

Given an array of positive integers and a number 'S', find the length of the smallest contiguous subarray whose sum is greater than of equal to 'S'. Return 0 if no such subarray exists.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
arr = [2, 1, 5, 2, 3, 2]
s = 7
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
smallest_subarray_sum(arr, s)

2
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)

{% raw %} 
assert smallest_subarray_sum(arr, s) == 2
{% endraw %}

Longest Substring with Maximum K Distinct Characters

Given a string find the length of the longest substring in it with no more than K distinct characters.

{% raw %}

longest_substring_with_k_distinct[source]

longest_substring_with_k_distinct(s, k)

Given a string find the length of the longest substring in it with no more than K distinct characters.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "araaci"
k = 2
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
longest_substring_with_k_distinct(s, k)

4
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert longest_substring_with_k_distinct(s, k) == 4
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(K)

Fruit into Basket

You are visiting a farm to collect fruits. The farm has a single row of fruit trees. You will be given two baskets, and your goal is to pick as many fruits as possible to be placed in the given baskets.

You will be given an array of characters where each character represents a fruit tree. The farm has following restrictions:> Each basket can have only one type of fruit. There is no limit to how many fruit a basket can hold. You can start with any tree, but you can’t skip a tree once you have started. You will pick exactly one fruit from every tree until you cannot, i.e., you will stop when you have to pick from a third fruit type.

Write a function to return the maximum number of fruits in both baskets.

{% raw %}

fruits_into_basket[source]

fruits_into_basket(fruits)

Variation of longest substring with k distinct characters.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
fruits = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'A', 'C']
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
fruits_into_basket(fruits)

3
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert fruits_into_basket(fruits) == 3
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
fruits = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'B', 'B', 'C']
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
fruits_into_basket(fruits)

5
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert fruits_into_basket(fruits) == 5
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)

Longest Substring with Distinct Characters

Given a string, find the length of the longest substring, which has all distinct characters.

{% raw %}

longest_substring_with_distinct_char[source]

longest_substring_with_distinct_char(s)

Given a string, find the length of the longest substring, which has all distinct characters.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "aabccbb"
longest_substring_with_distinct_char(s)

3
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert longest_substring_with_distinct_char(s) == 3
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(26) so O(1)

Longest Substring with Same Letters after Replacement

Given a string with lowercase letters only, if you are allowed to replace no more than k letters with any letter, find the length of the longest substring having the same letters after replacement.

{% raw %}

length_of_longest_substring[source]

length_of_longest_substring(arr, k)

Given an array containing 0s and 1s, if you are allowed to replace no more than ‘k’ 0s with 1s, find the length of the longest contiguous subarray having all 1s.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "aabccbb"
k = 2
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
length_of_longest_substring(s, k)

5
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert length_of_longest_substring(s, k) == 5
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(26) so O(1)

Longest Substring with Ones after Replacement

Given an array containing 0s and 1s, if you are allowed to replace no more than ‘k’ 0s with 1s, find the length of the longest contiguous subarray having all 1s.

{% raw %}

length_of_longest_substring[source]

length_of_longest_substring(arr, k)

Given an array containing 0s and 1s, if you are allowed to replace no more than ‘k’ 0s with 1s, find the length of the longest contiguous subarray having all 1s.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
arr = [0, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1]
k = 2
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
length_of_longest_substring(arr, k)

6
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert length_of_longest_substring(arr, k) == 6
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N)
Space Complexity: O(1)

Permutation in a String

Given a string and a pattern, find out if the string contains any permutation of the pattern.

Permutation is defined as the re-arranging of the characters of the string. For example, “abc” has the following six permutations:> abc acb bac bca cab cba

If a string has ‘n’ distinct characters, it will have n!n!n! permutations.

{% raw %}

find_permutation[source]

find_permutation(s, pattern)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "oidbcaf"
pattern = "abc"
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
find_permutation(s, pattern)

True
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert find_permutation(s, pattern) == True
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N+M)
Space Complexity: O(M)

where N and M are the number of characters in the input string and pattern, respectively.

String Anagrams

Given a string and a pattern, find all anagrams of the pattern in the given string.

Every anagram is a permutation of a string. As we know, when we are not allowed to repeat characters while finding permutations of a string, we get N!N!N! permutations (or anagrams) of a string having NNN characters. For example, here are the six anagrams of the string “abc”:> abc acb bac bca cab cba

Write a function to return a list of starting indices of the anagrams of the pattern in the given string.

{% raw %}

find_string_anagrams[source]

find_string_anagrams(s, pattern)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "ppqp"
pattern = "pq"
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
find_string_anagrams(s, pattern)

[1, 2]
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert find_string_anagrams(s, pattern) == [1, 2]
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N+M)
Space Complexity: O(M) / O(N) worst case

Smallest Window containing Substring

Given a string and a pattern, find the smallest substring in the given string which has all the character occurrences of the given pattern.

{% raw %}

find_substring[source]

find_substring(s, pattern)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "aabdec"
pattern = "abc"
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
find_substring(s, pattern)

'abdec'
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert find_substring(s, pattern) == 'abdec'
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N+M)
Space Complexity: O(M)

Word Concatentation

Given a string and a list of words, find all the starting indices of substrings in the given string that are a concatenation of all the given words exactly once without any overlapping of words. It is given that all words are of the same length.

{% raw %}

find_word_concatenation[source]

find_word_concatenation(s, words)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
s = "catfoxcat"
words = ["cat", "fox"]
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
find_word_concatenation(s, words)

[0, 3]
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert find_word_concatenation(s, words) == [0, 3]
{% endraw %}

Time Complexity: O(N M Len) Space Complexity: (N+M)

where N is the number of characters, M is the total number of words, and Len is the length of a word.
O(M) storing all the words in two hashmaps, O(N) space for the resulting list.
